newsitem.title: CHINA: Shanghai copper ends mostly up on LME gains.
newsitem.headline: Shanghai copper ends mostly up on LME gains.

text.p: Shanghai copper futures ended mostly up on Thursday on overnight gains on the London Metal Exchange (LME), traders said.
The most activly traded August 1998 contract ended up at an intraday low of 23,450 yuan ($2,827) per tonne, rising 90 yuan. It opened at a high of 23,600 yuan per tonne.
May was unchanged at 23,300 yuan, June rose 20 to 23,400, July 120 to 23,470, September 130 to 23,480, October 110 to 23,400 yuan.
Combined volume fell to 29,550 tonnes from 30,460 tonnes.
Copper opened higher but profit-taking prevented the red metal from rising further for most of the session.
Traders said LME gains on Wednesday had spurred the confidence of long position holders but local copper met strong selling pressure at high levels.
"Investors took advantage of the LME gains to liquidate their long positions at high levels," one trader said, adding investors were unsure what direction the market would take.
LME copper traded in a sideways band on Wednesday but after a positive close at $2,368/70 were forecast to test overhead resistance on Thursday.
The physical price is around 23,300 yuan per tonne in the Shanghai area.

Trading sources predicted a rise in physical prices in the short term on rumours that a shipment of about 1,000 tonnes of copper had been held up at Shanghai port. The market talk could not be confirmed with customs authorities.
Traders said active domestic A shares were attracting the attention of many investors.
"More and more investors want to enter the stock market for quick profits," a second trader said.
Analysts said they expected copper to move above the key support level of 23,000 yuan in the next few days.
Aluminium ended up. May rose 30 yuan to 15,300, June 50 to 15,600, July 300 to 15,900 and the first traded August 1998 contract ended at 16,050.
Combined volume rose to 1,340 tonnes from 800 tonnes.
